Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: New Formulation and Algorithms for Fluid-Structure Interaction, with Application to Tumor Growth
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fluid-structure interaction (FSI) problems play prominent roles in many scientific and engineering fields, yet an accurate study of such problems remains highly challenging due to the strong nonlinearity and multi-physics involved. Current computational theory and methods for fluid-structure interactions lack sufficient accuracy and realistic material representations, and are limited to relatively simple structural configurations. The goal of this project is to overcome such limitations by establishing a new computational mathematical framework for accurate and efficient numerical investigation of complex FSI problems, particularly for tumor growth modeling and simulation. The PIs will derive new mathematical formulation that allows the study of general FSI problems with sophisticated structural settings, develop efficient numerical algorithms that ensure high accuracy in FSI computations, and apply the proposed mathematical formulation and computational methods to the individual-cell-based modeling and simulation of tumor growth. This proposal builds on the PIs? solid background in computational and applied mathematics and significant work on tumor modeling.

The proposed research will improve the understanding of the nonlinear dynamics in highly complex FSI problems through a combined mathematical and computational framework. Experimental measurements will also be used for validating the numerical results. The success of this project will not only provide a solid knowledge base for advancing the current state of computational FSI study, but also enable important discoveries in the fundamental mechanism of early tumor formation and development. The project experiences and findings will strengthen the research collaboration and curriculum development in computational mathematics and mathematical biology at both Old Dominion University and the College of William and Mary. Due to the close geographical proximity between the two schools, project impacts will be maximized through convenient communication between faculty and students and through joint programs between the two schools. Education and outreach activities will involve graduate and undergraduate students in the theory, methods and application of computational mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcome Summary:

Solid brain tumors, particularly, gliomas, are highly lethal and notably resistant to standard therapies. It is very important to understand how the tumor is developed and grows under therapies in order to treat them. This project collaborated with physicians to build mathematical models based on fluid dynamics and applied new effective computational algorithms to solve the mathematical models. Numerical simulations and analytical studies of the mathematical models deepen our understanding of relevant biological and medical issues. Particularly, the project has involved gliom virotherapy, infiltrating dynamics of immune cells into the tumor, stochastic growth patterns of gliomas, infectious disease spreading, and maturation effect in plankton systems. In the meantime, this award has enabled the PI to establish his research group with graduate education in minority-serving institution - New Mexico State University (NMSU), which strengthens the interdisciplinary training programs for current and future underserved scientists in NMSU.

Intellectual Merit:

1) One major challenge of oncolytic virotherapy is the complexity of the immune responses. This project proposed a new mathematical modeling framework based on fluid dynamics to study tumor virotherapy with mediated immunity. The project did deep studies that incorporates the innate immune response into the basic mathematical model for virotherapy as 4-dimensional systems, and investigated how the innate immune response affects the efficacy of oncolytic viral therapy. This project also incorporated virus lytic cycle as a delay parameter and found a functional relation between virus burst size and lytic cycle, which has a profound impact on viral therapy. When we modify the virus burst size, and consequently change the virus lytic cycle.   2) Infiltrating dynamics of immune cells into the tumor is very important. Although tumor-infiltrated immune cells consist of a significant component of many cancers and their role remains elusive, an understanding of how the infiltration of immune cells into tumors is regulated is essentially important. Based on recent experimental results about mutant IDH1, the project proposed and analyzed a mathematical model for the infiltrating dynamics of immune cells into tumors.   3) Knowledge of growth rates and underlying growth patterns of human gliomas is useful for planning treatment logistics. From repeated pretreatment contrast-enhanced T1-weighted MRI scans with 94 untreated human glioblastoma data sets, the project built a new type of Gompertz diffusion model for untreated human glioma growth. This SDE model not only captures the average growth pattern and the variance among individual patients, but can also predict individual glioblastoma growth paths. The empirical distribution of survival times simulated from the model can be used to calculate a patient's survival times for performing surgery on glioblastoma patients.   4) To understand maturation delay in plankton system, the project revisited the minimal model for a plankton ecosystem with spatial diffusion of plankton and delay of the maturation period of herbivorous zooplankton. The study deepened our understanding of effects of the nutrients and the predation of fish upon zooplankton on the dynamical patterns of the plankton system, and presented new phenomena induced by the delay with spatial diffusion.   5) In a study on infectious disease spreading dynamics, the project established a mathematical model for a complexity phenomenon that emerges from epidemiology, which is not derived from bifurcation phenomena mathematically.      

Broader Impacts

1) This project integrated research and education to offer training opportunities to undergraduate and graduate students. Undergraduate and graduate students had research experience during summers in the PI group, and one graduate student worked on topics related to the project towards his thesis. The PI hold Math Biology Seminars and problems and results of the project were discussed in the seminars as educational materials.  2) The project recruited several URM undergraduate and graduate students for research experience.  3) The project invited distinguished researchers to visit NMSU and gave public lectures, which enhanced the educational environment of NMSU and also disseminates the research impacts internationally.  4) The activities of the PI gave talks/lectures conferences and other universities, and special sessions organized by the PI in professional meetings broadened dissemination of the research results.  5) The project mainly modeled several mechanisms of immune responses in oncolytic virotherapy, infiltrating dynamics of immune cells into the tumor, and stochastic human glioma growth patterns. These outcomes will directly impact cancer biology and treatments.  It will contribute to understanding the health aspect of the public welfare and contribute the well-being of our society.
